title: 114_s385
content: The "Biennial Appropriations Act" is cited as the short title. Section 300 of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to revise the timetable for the congressional budget process. The timetable for the congressional budget process includes deadlines for the President to submit the budget, reports to be submitted by the Congressional Budget Office and Committees, completion of actions on concurrent resolutions and reconciliation legislation, and consideration of appropriation bills in the House. The congressional budget process includes deadlines for completing action on biennial appropriation bills and the defense appropriation bill by June 30 in the House and August 1 in Congress. The fiscal year begins on October 1. In the case of the first session of Congress following a leap year, with a new President, specific dates will override the usual deadlines for budget actions. The budget timeline includes key deadlines such as the President submitting the budget by the first Monday in April, Congressional Budget Office submitting a report by April 15, Committees submitting views by April 20, Budget Committees reporting by May 15, and Congress completing action on the budget by June 1. Biennial appropriation bills and defense appropriation bills may be considered in the House by July 1, with House action completed by July 20, and Congress completing action on appropriation bills by August 1. On August 1, Congress completes action on biennial appropriation bills and defense appropriation bill. On October 1, the fiscal year begins. In odd-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Financial Services, Transportation, Housing and Urban Development, Interior, Environment, Labor, Health and Human Services, Education, and Military Construction, Veterans Affairs. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts an annual defense appropriation bill and biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture and Commerce, Justice, Science. In even-numbered years, Congress enacts biennial appropriation bills for Agriculture, Commerce, Justice, Science, Energy and Water, Homeland Security, Legislative Branch, and State-Foreign Operations. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS TO THE CONGRESSIONAL BUDGET AND IMPOUNDMENT CONTROL ACT OF 1974. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. The Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to define a biennium as a 2-year period starting on October 1. Committee allocations are adjusted to include appropriations for each fiscal year in the biennium and the first fiscal year for defense. Amendments include changes to subsections (b) and (f)(2)(A) regarding budget years and fiscal years covered by the resolution. SEC. 4. AMENDMENTS TO TITLE 31, UNITED STATES CODE. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code include defining 'biennium' and adjusting budget contents and submission to Congress for fiscal years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references from "the fiscal year" to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for balance statements, functions, activities, allowances, tax expenditures, and future years. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references to fiscal years to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections, including future years, prior year outlays, and prior year receipts. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references to fiscal years to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections, including future years, prior year outlays, and prior year receipts. This includes adjustments to prior year receipts, estimated expenditures of legislative and judicial branches, and recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies. Amendments to Title 31, United States Code involve changing references to fiscal years to "each fiscal year in the biennium" for various sections. This includes adjustments to prior year receipts, estimated expenditures of legislative and judicial branches, and recommendations to meet estimated deficiencies. Additionally, Section 1105(e)(1) of title 31, United States Code is amended to replace "ensuing fiscal year" with "biennium to which such budget relates". SEC. 5. Two-year appropriations; title and style of appropriations acts. Section 105 of title 1, United States Code, is amended to specify the title and style of appropriations Acts for nondefense and defense purposes. Nondefense Acts will follow a specific format for each fiscal year in a biennium, while defense Acts will have a different format. All Acts making regular appropriations must detail the amounts provided for each fiscal year. The term 'biennium' is defined as in the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974. Acts described in subsection (a)(1) will be treated according to the Congressional Budget Act of 1974. A technical amendment is made to the table of sections for chapter 2 of title 1, United States Code. SEC. 6. MULTIYEAR AUTHORIZATIONS. Title III of the Congressional Budget Act of 1974 is amended to include authorizations of appropriations. Sec. 316 prohibits considering bills authorizing appropriations for less than 2 fiscal years in the House or Senate unless no further appropriations are needed. Exceptions include defense, privileged measures, Executive Session matters, and appropriations or reconciliation bills. Amendment to the Congressional Budget and Impoundment Control Act of 1974 to add a new item after section 315 related to appropriations measures or reconciliation bills. SEC. 7. CONGRESSIONAL OVERSIGHT. Congressional committees must hold joint oversight hearings on agency activities in non-funded years. The hearings review the agency's mission, impact of biennial budgeting, cost savings, new programs, and terminated programs. SEC. 8. REPORT ON TWO-YEAR FISCAL PERIOD. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget will study the impact of changing to a 2-year fiscal period with a biennial budget process and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees on the Budget within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act and its amendments will take effect on January 1, 2016, applying to budget resolutions and appropriations for the biennium starting in fiscal year 2017.
